property.name: _windowProperties
property.value: {bounds={143, 41, 1297, 679}, maximized=false}

property.name: text
property.value:
This demo takes in Scarab's pose and a lightMap in JSON form. It sends light data to a Hue accessor to manipulate a set of Hue lights.
The 'engine' JavaScript actor runs the following computation: At a set interval, it gets the nearest bulb to the Scarab. If this bulb is closer than a set threshold, the light is sent the set light conditions. The light conditions, interval and threshold are all parameters.
Another accessor could be developed to create the lightMap when the Scarab is in mapping mode.

property.name: script
description
property.value:
This accessor controls a Philips Hue lightbulb.

It sets the parameters of the specified light according to the input values.

Logging on: This script attempts to access the bridge as a user with name given by userName, which defaults to "ptolemyuser". If there is no such user on the bridge, the script registers such a user and requests (via an alert dialog) that the link button on the bridge be pushed to authorize registration of this user. The user is given 20s to do this before an exception is thrown If it fails to reach the bridge, it will try again a few times before giving up.

Verifying the light: The final initialization step is to get a list of accessible lights. If the input light is not accessible, this accessor warns but does not error. Sometimes Hue lights are transient (get unplugged, become temporarily disconnected) and may be valid in the future. Rather than terminating the model, we hope that the lights come back.

Discovery: Finding the IP address of the Hue Bridge is not necessarily easy. The bridge acquires its address via DHCP, so the address will typically change each time the bridge is rebooted. Moreover, the address will likely not be accessible except on the local network. The bridge responds to UPnP packets (universal plug-and-play), so it is possible to use software such as Cling to discover the bridge. Ideally, UPnP discover would be provided via an accessor. In this case, a swarmlet could be created that runs periodically on a local network and publishes the URL of any discovered bridges to a key-value store. Then the KeyValueStore accessor could be used to provide the bridgeIPAdress input to this accessor.

property.name: author
property.value: Edward A. Lee, Marcus Pan

property.name: userName (parameter)
property.value: The user name for logging on to the Hue Bridge. This must be at least 11 characters, or the Hue regards it as invalid.

property.name: bridgeIPAddress (port)
property.value: The bridge IP address (and port, if needed).

property.name: lightID (port)
property.value: The light identifier (an integer beginning with 1).

property.name: brightness (port)
property.value: The brightness (an integer between 0 and 255).

property.name: hue (port)
property.value: The hue (an integer between 0 and 62580).

property.name: saturation (port)
property.value: The saturation (an integer between 0 and 255).

property.name: transitionTime (port)
property.value: The transition time, in multiples of 100ms.

property.name: trigger (port)
property.value: Triggers a PUT request with all the light settings. Can be any type.

property.name: on (port)
property.value: Whether the light is on (true) or off (false).

property.name: script
description
property.value:
This accessor subscribes to a pre-established ROS topic.
It communicates to ROS through the rosbridge web socket, and extends the WebSocketClient accessor to do so. It has a 'topic' parameter, that must be prefixed with a '/' eg: '/noise'.
. The other parameters configure how the data is to be received according to the rosbridge specification: https://github.com/RobotWebTools/rosbridge_suite/blob/develop/ROSBRIDGE_PROTOCOL.md#344-subscribe

property.name: author
property.value: Marcus Pan, Matt Weber

property.name: topic (parameter)
property.value: The ROS topic to subscribe to.

property.name: toSend
property.value: The data to be send to the web socket server, in JSON format.

property.name: connected (port)
property.value: The status of the web socket connection.

property.name: received (port)
property.value: The data received from the web socket server.

property.name: throttle_rate (parameter)
property.value: ({names:["int"]}) The minimum amount of time (in ms) that must elapse between messages sent. Defaults to 0.

property.name: queue_length (parameter)
property.value: ({names:["int"]}) The ROS size of the queue to buffer messages. Messages are buffered as a result of the throttle_rate. Defaults to 1.

property.name: fragment_size (parameter)
property.value: The maximum size that a message can take before it is to be fragmented. Defaults to 1000. Ptolemy will close the model if fragment size is too large (not sure what the maximum is).

property.name: compression (parameter)
property.value: A string to specify the compression scheme to be used on messages. Options are "none" (default) and "png".

property.name: throttleRate (parameter)
property.value: The minimum amount of time (in ms) that must elapse between messages sent. Defaults to 0.

property.name: queueLength (parameter)
property.value: The ROS size of the queue to buffer messages. Messages are buffered as a result of the throttleRate. Defaults to 1.

property.name: outputCompleteResponseOnly (parameter)
property.value: A flag which if set to true will cause the accessor to delay in sending messages on the "received" port until it has concatenated the data fields from message fragments back into the original unfragmented message. Otherwise it will send the message fragments as they come in.

property.name: _windowProperties
property.value: {bounds={1172, 293, 170, 193}, maximized=false}

property.name: script
